channelMix.correctionInsight: Email is 51.3% of all tickets — not 9%. Post Help Center launch, the old Email workflow was migrated to EmailCase. These are the same channel, different routing. EmailCase (28.5%) + Email legacy (22.8%) = 51.3% of all volume. The Help Center reduced email's SHARE but email remains the dominant channel by a wide margin.

grouped.breakdown: Direct agent assignment — device verification specialist
Only 61 direct HC tickets — most HC users go through bot/chat first

shiftAnnotations.label: In-App: 5% → 20% (+15pp)
shiftAnnotations.note: Mostly Device Verification auto-tickets, not true channel shift

shiftAnnotations.label: Live Chat: 24% → 11% (−13pp)
shiftAnnotations.note: Genuine shift — users going through bot instead

channelMix.shiftInsight: The HC launch shifted channel mix but didn't reduce email dominance. Email dropped from 57% to 45% share — but it's still 51.3% of cumulative volume. The real shift was Live Chat (−13pp) as users now enter through the bot. In-App growth is misleading — 77% is auto-created Device Verification tickets, not users choosing In-App.

fcrByChannel.insight: Worst FCR — bot-escalated tickets need repeat contact
Highest volume + low FCR = biggest absolute rework
Users call when other channels failed — repeat is about the issue, not the channel
Specialist channel — lower volume but complex cases
Moderate FCR — live agents resolve most in-session
Legacy email — higher FCR than EmailCase (more mature workflow)
High FCR — but 49% stuck in Waiting on User (auto-tickets)

resolution.fcrCategoryInsight: Security & Fraud (51.4% FCR) and Account Management (66.2% FCR) are the hardest categories to resolve. Account Management alone generates 1,331 multi-touch clusters — 17.6% of all repeat contacts. These are issues like phone number changes, KYC verification, and account reactivation that require backend system actions no article or bot can perform today.

customerEffort.label: HIGH
customerEffort.reason: 10.2% L2 escalation, 4.2% merge rate, 2.2% customer inactive

effortCost.costSignal: HIGHEST — high volume × high rework = maximum cost
MEDIUM — high volume but efficient processing
LOW per-ticket but high customer effort before reaching agent

agentEffort.label: HIGH
agentEffort.reason: 49% stuck in Waiting on User, only 46% close

effortCost.costSignal: WASTED — 49% of tickets never engage. Agent checks tickets that go nowhere.

customerEffort.label: HIGH
customerEffort.reason: Users call when other channels fail — 23.4% visited HC first

agentEffort.label: MEDIUM
agentEffort.reason: 100% close, 0% rework — but synchronous = expensive per minute

effortCost.costSignal: HIGH per-ticket — synchronous channel with 100% resolution but highest unit cost

customerEffort.label: MEDIUM
customerEffort.reason: Specialist routing — users directed here by other agents

effortCost.costSignal: EFFICIENT — specialist channel with good resolution

customerEffort.label: HIGH
customerEffort.reason: 71.4% FCR (worst), bot added 15.6 turns of friction before handoff

agentEffort.label: LOW
agentEffort.reason: 2% rework, 98% close — agent resolves quickly once reached

effortCost.costSignal: Bot creates customer effort, but agent resolves efficiently once involved

patterns.interpretation: Email can't resolve → specialist agent needed
Email too slow → tried real-time channel
New email → then tried bot (reverse expected flow)
Email unresolved → called for immediate help
Email user also triggered In-App ticket

patterns.pattern: EmailCase + L1 Agent + Live Chatbot Case

switching.patternInsight: The #1 switch pattern is EmailCase → L1 Agent (1,674 clusters). This means email agents can't resolve the issue and must hand off to specialists. The user waits for email reply, gets re-routed, waits again. The #2 pattern (Email → Live Chat, 728) shows users giving up on async email and trying real-time. Both patterns are effort signals — the user is doing the work the system should automate.

mergedAndSwitched.insight: 37% of merged-ticket users also switched channels

mergedAndL2.insight: 14% of merged-ticket users also hit L2 escalation

switchedAndL2.insight: 37.5% of channel-switchers also had L2 escalation

allThree.insight: 141 users had merged tickets + channel switch + L2 escalation — maximum effort population

merged.mergedInsight: Merged tickets are a direct cost multiplier. 1,380 tickets merged = duplicate work for agents. 37% of merged-ticket users also switched channels, meaning they created duplicates BECAUSE they didn't get a response in the first channel. The correlation between merging, switching, and L2 escalation (141 users experienced all three) proves these aren't independent problems — they're the same failure cascade.

inAppStatus.note: 77% of In-App tickets are Device Verification. 49% sit in 'Waiting on User' forever — the user never responds because they already resolved it themselves or abandoned.

deviceVerification.insight: Device Verification creates 6,553 tickets (11.1% of all volume) with no customer-initiated action. The app auto-creates a ticket when a new device is detected. 77% come through In-App, and 49% of those stay in "Waiting on User" permanently. This is phantom volume — no customer asked for help, no resolution is needed, but agents must check each one. This single sub-category creates more tickets than Phone, L1 Agent, or Social channels.

recommendation.title: Replace Ticket Creation with System-State Awareness

proposedFlow.label: OR: "Still need help?" → specialist WITH context

proposedStats.agentTime: Zero for resolved, minimal for escalated

alertExamples: Your withdrawal of Rp 500,000 via BCA is processing (est. 1-2 business days)
Your KYC verification is pending review (est. 24 hours)
Your new device was detected — tap to verify
technicalRequirements: Identity resolution: User must be authenticated (logged in) when reaching HC
Backend API: Real-time read from admin.pluang.com status endpoints
Frontend: Dynamic alert component on HC landing page (post-login)
Fallback: "Still need help?" button → direct to specialist agent (not general bot)
Context pass-through: When user clicks "Still need help?", their system state + issue type is passed to agent — zero re-collection needed

whyBetter.result: Reduces failure from 67.7% to maybe 40% — still requires user to describe issue
Reduces response time from 3 days to 1 day — still creates a ticket
ELIMINATES the contact entirely for status-check issues
